Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. 19,605,052 [[stock|shares]] were offered at a price of $85 per share.<ref name="IPO">Elgin, Ben. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm Google: Whiz Kids or Naughty Boys?]" ''[[Business Week]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> Of that, 14,142,135 (another mathematical reference as [[Square root of two|â2]] â 1.4142135) were floated by Google and 5,462,917 by selling stockholders. The sale raised [[United States dollar|$]]1.67 Billion, and gave Google a [[market capitalization]] of more than $23 Billion.<ref name="washpost"/> The vast majority of Google's 271 million shares remained under Google's control. Many of Google's employees became instant paper millionaires. [[Yahoo!]], a competitor of Google, also benefited from the IPO because it owns 2.7 million shares of Google.<ref name="yahooshares">Kuchinskas, Susan. "[http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/3392781 Yahoo and Google Settle]." ''[http://www.internetnews.com/ internetnews.com].'' [[August 9]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref>
Google's initial public offering took place on [[August 19]], [[2004]]. 19,605,052 [[stock|shares]] were offered at a price of $85 per share.<ref name="IPO">Elgin, Ben. "[http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/aug2004/tc20040819_6843_tc120.htm Google: Whiz Kids or Naughty Boys?]" ''[[Business Week]].'' [[August 19]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref> Of that, 14,142,135 (another mathematical reference as [[Square root of two|â2]] â 1.4142135) were floated by Google and 5,462,917 by selling stockholders. The sale raised [[United States dollar|$]]1.67 Billion, and gave Google a [[market capitalization]] of more than $23 Billion.<ref name="washpost"/> The vast majority of Google's 271 million shares remained under Google's control. Many of Google's employees became instant paper millionaires. [[Yahoo!]], a competitor of Google, also benefited from the IPO because it owns 2.7 million shares of Google.<ref name="yahooshares">Kuchinskas, Susan. "[http://www.internetnews.com/bus-news/article.php/3392781 Yahoo and Google Settle]." ''[http://www.internetnews.com/ internetnews.com].'' [[August 9]], [[2004]]. Retrieved on [[February 25]], [[2007]].</ref>
â
Google's post-IPO stock performance has been very good as well, with shares surging to $300 by [[2005]], due to strong sales and earnings in the advertising market, as well as the release of new features like the [[Google Desktop|desktop search function]] and personalized home page.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle">La Monica, Paul R. "[http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/25/technology/techinvestor/lamonica/index.htm Bowling for Google]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[May 25]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 28]], [[2007]].</ref> The surge in stock price is fueled primarily by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and [[mutual fund]]s.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle"/>
+
Google's post-IPO stock performance has been very good as well, with shares surging to $500 by [[2007]], due to strong sales and earnings in the advertising market, as well as the release of new features like the [[Google Desktop|desktop search function]] and personalized home page.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle">La Monica, Paul R. "[http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/25/technology/techinvestor/lamonica/index.htm Bowling for Google]." ''[[CNN]].'' [[May 25]], [[2005]]. Retrieved on [[February 28]], [[2007]].</ref> The surge in stock price is fueled primarily by individual investors, as opposed to large institutional investors and [[mutual fund]]s.<ref name="bowlingforgoogle"/>
The company is listed on the [[NASDAQ]] stock exchange under the [[ticker]] symbol '''GOOG'''.
The company is listed on the [[NASDAQ]] stock exchange under the [[ticker]] symbol '''GOOG'''.
